countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggerspieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improperly configured IAM policies can lead to unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly configured IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies in AWS can result in unauthorized access to DynamoDB tables. These policies govern who can access what resources and with what permissions. Misconfigurations can accidentally grant excessive privileges, allowing unauthorized users to read, write, or delete data, thereby compromising the security of the DynamoDB service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include internal users such as employees or administrators who might misconfigure policies either accidentally or intentionally. External attackers can exploit stolen AWS credentials or use social engineering techniques to gain access. Automation tools with misconfigured permissions can also inadvertently expose sensitive data.

Impacts

The impacts of this threat include data breaches where sensitive information is exposed, data integrity issues from unauthorized modifications, service disruptions due to unauthorized configuration changes, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator accidentally grants excessive permissions to a DynamoDB table, allowing unauthorized internal applications to modify data. A phishing attack leads to compromised AWS credentials, which are then used to exploit an overly permissive policy, resulting in a data breach. A malicious insider with policy management privileges misconfigures policies to gain access to sensitive data, leaking it to external parties. An automation script with broad IAM permissions inadvertently changes access controls, exposing data to unauthorized users.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data transmitted over the network can be intercepted by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted over a network can be intercepted by malicious actors using various techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or session hijacking. In the context of AWS DynamoDB, data in transit between clients and the database service may be vulnerable if not adequately protected. Intercepted data can lead to exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access, and manipulation of data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include cybercriminals, hackers, or state-sponsored actors who intercept data using MitM attacks, deploying tools to capture network traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in network security protocols. These attackers may gain access through compromised network infrastructure, unsecured Wi-Fi networks, or by exploiting weak encryption standards.

Impacts

The interception of data in transit can result in data breaches, exposing sensitive information such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property. It can also lead to unauthorized data manipulation, where the integrity and authenticity of the data are compromised. Additionally, it may cause loss of trust, reputational damage, and potential legal consequences for failing to protect customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

A hacker sets up a MitM attack on an unsecured Wi-Fi network, intercepting data transmitted between a client application and the DynamoDB service, capturing sensitive information like authentication tokens and customer data. An attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to monitor and extract data being transferred in plaintext due to lack of encryption. A cybercriminal exploits a vulnerability in a network protocol to hijack an active session between a user and the DynamoDB service, gaining unauthorized access to modify and steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Without proper monitoring, security incidents can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Without proper monitoring, security incidents involving AWS DynamoDB can go undetected, allowing malicious activities to persist and causing prolonged exposure to threats. Continuous monitoring is essential for detecting unauthorized access, suspicious activities, and potential security breaches in real-time. Lack of monitoring can result in delayed response to security incidents, increasing the risk of data compromise and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated threats such as malware. Attack vectors can involve exploiting vulnerabilities, using stolen credentials, and performing unauthorized data access or modifications. Absence of monitoring tools and alerting mechanisms makes it easier for these threats to operate undetected over extended periods.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents can lead to severe impacts, including prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, extensive data breaches, significant financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, prolonged exposure increases the complexity and cost of incident response and recovery, while also potentially resulting in regulatory non-compliance and legal penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

An external attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain access to DynamoDB and exfiltrates sensitive data over several months without detection due to lack of monitoring. A malicious insider continuously accesses and manipulates confidential information in DynamoDB, undetected due to insufficient logging and alerting. Malware infects an application accessing DynamoDB, gradually exfiltrating data without triggering any alerts because of inadequate monitoring. Anomalous access patterns indicating a security breach go unnoticed due to the absence of real-time monitoring and analysis tools.

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in AWS DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access. This can occur due to misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, lack of encryption, or insufficient monitoring. Ensuring that sensitive information such as personal, financial, or proprietary data is protected is critical to maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders with sufficient access privileges, external attackers exploiting misconfigured permissions or vulnerabilities, and automated scripts or applications with excessive access rights. Attack vectors can include exploiting weak or default configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or taking advantage of unencrypted data storage.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive data can lead to significant consequences such as identity theft, financial loss, damage to reputation, and legal penalties for non-compliance with data protection regulations. Organizations may face operational disruptions, loss of customer trust, and competitive disadvantages if proprietary information is leaked.

Example Attack Scenarios

An insider with administrative privileges accesses and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in DynamoDB for personal gain. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to gain unauthorized access to financial records stored in DynamoDB. A developer accidentally deploys an application with excessive permissions, allowing it to read and expose sensitive data. Lack of encryption at rest results in an attacker accessing unprotected sensitive information directly from the storage medium.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Auto Scaling data at rest and in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data related to AWS Auto Scaling, including configuration files and logs, is encrypted both at rest and in transit using AWS encryption services.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Store configuration files in S3 or EFS with server-side encryption using AWS KMS.
  • Encrypt CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs using AWS KMS.

Encrypt Data in Transit:

  • Use HTTPS (TLS) for data transmission.

Manage Access:

  • Apply IAM policies for least privilege access to encryption keys.

Monitor Compliance:

  • Use AWS Config to ensure encryption policies are followed.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement service-linked roles for Auto Scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Implement service-linked roles for AWS Auto Scaling to provide permissions for AWS services to perform actions on your behalf securely. This ensures that Auto Scaling can function properly while adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Create Service-Linked Role:

  • Use the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK to create a service-linked role specifically for Auto Scaling.
  • The role is predefined with the necessary permissions for Auto Scaling to operate securely.

Assign Service-Linked Role:

  • Ensure that the Auto Scaling service is using the created service-linked role to perform its operations.

Review Role Permissions:

  • Regularly review the permissions assigned to the service-linked role to ensure they are up to date and adhere to security best practices.

Monitor Role Activity:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log the activities performed by the service-linked role for auditing and compliance purposes.

By following these steps, you can securely delegate necessary permissions to AWS Auto Scaling while maintaining tight security controls.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Restrict traffic with security groups for Auto Scaling instances
countermeasure.desc:
Configure security groups to restrict traffic to and from AWS Auto Scaling instances, allowing only necessary ports and protocols. This enhances security by limiting exposure to potential threats.

Create Security Groups:

  • Define security groups specifically for Auto Scaling instances.

Restrict Inbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary inbound ports and protocols (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS for web servers, SSH for management).
  • Specify trusted IP ranges for access where applicable.

Restrict Outbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary outbound ports and protocols required for instance functionality.

Regularly Review and Update Rules:

  • Periodically audit security group rules to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege.
  • Adjust rules as necessary based on changes in application requirements or security policies.

countermeasure.name: Test scaling policies in staging environment
countermeasure.desc:
Test all AWS Auto Scaling policies in a staging environment before deploying them to production. This ensures their effectiveness and stability, minimizing the risk of configuration errors that could impact application performance and availability.

Set Up Staging Environment:

  • Mirror the production environment in staging to accurately test scaling policies.

Deploy and Test:

  • Implement scaling policies in the staging environment.
  • Conduct load tests and monitor the behavior of the scaling policies under various scenarios.

Review and Adjust:

  • Analyze test results and adjust policies as necessary to ensure optimal performance and stability.

Deploy to Production:

  • Once verified, apply the tested and adjusted scaling policies to the production environment.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Auto Scaling resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to AWS Auto Scaling resources can result in unintended changes to scaling policies, unauthorized scaling actions, and potential misuse of resources, leading to performance issues and security breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM credentials
    • Misconfigured IAM roles and policies
    • Exploiting application vulnerabilities
    • Lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA)

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive configuration data
  • Operational Disruption: Service performance issues
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to unauthorized scaling actions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen AWS credentials to modify Auto Scaling policies, leading to resource misuse.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Roles: Broad permissions in IAM roles allow unauthorized changes to Auto Scaling settings.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee alters scaling policies to disrupt services.
  4. Application Exploitation: Exploiting a vulnerability to gain elevated permissions and change Auto Scaling configurations.

Implementing strict IAM policies, enabling MFA, regularly auditing roles, and monitoring activities can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breaches due to insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Data breaches due to insufficient data protection in AWS Auto Scaling involve unauthorized access to sensitive data because of inadequate encryption, misconfiguration, or weak data handling practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted data at rest or in transit
    • Misconfigured storage settings
    • Exploitation of weak access controls
    • Insufficient data handling practices

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Exposure of sensitive data, such as customer information or proprietary business data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized modification of data
  • Operational Disruption: Service interruptions and loss of data integrity
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Potential fines and legal action due to failure to comply with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage: An attacker gains access to unencrypted storage containing sensitive data, leading to data theft.
  2. Misconfigured Permissions: Improper configuration of S3 bucket permissions results in public access to sensitive data.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee with access to sensitive data exports it without proper authorization.
  4. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data in transit due to lack of encryption, gaining access to sensitive information.

Implementing data encryption, configuring storage settings securely, enforcing strict access controls, and following best practices for data handling can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Misconfiguration of AWS Auto Scaling policies can lead to improper scaling actions, resulting in over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources. This can negatively impact application performance, availability, and cost efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Developers, DevOps engineers, external attackers (through compromised accounts)
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Incorrect scaling thresholds and metrics
    • Overly aggressive or conservative scaling policies
    • Manual errors during policy configuration
    • Lack of testing and validation for scaling policies

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning leads to unnecessary costs, while under-provisioning causes performance degradation.
  • Operational Disruption: Unstable application performance and potential downtime.
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to inefficient resource scaling.
  • Reputation Damage: Customer dissatisfaction due to poor application performance and reliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Thresholds: A developer sets CPU utilization thresholds too low, causing Auto Scaling to add more instances than necessary, leading to high costs.
  2. Overly Aggressive Scaling: An overly aggressive scaling policy scales up resources too quickly in response to minor traffic spikes, resulting in resource waste.
  3. Lack of Testing: A misconfigured scaling policy is applied directly to production without testing, leading to unexpected behavior and service disruptions.
  4. Manual Configuration Errors: An engineer manually configures a scaling policy with incorrect parameters, causing the application to scale inadequately during peak load.

By implementing these countermeasures, you can mitigate the risks associated with misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies and ensure that your application scales efficiently and cost-effectively.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Network vulnerabilities in AWS Auto Scaling involve weaknesses in the network configuration that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access, disrupt services, or exfiltrate data. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper network segmentation, insecure protocols, or misconfigured network security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of open ports and services
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks
    • DDoS attacks targeting network infrastructure
    • Exploiting insecure network protocols

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive data and resources
  • Data Breach: Exposure of confidential information
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degraded performance due to network attacks
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to perceived security weaknesses
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with mitigating breaches and service disruptions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Ports: An attacker scans for and exploits open ports on Auto Scaling instances, gaining unauthorized access to the network.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts and alters communications between Auto Scaling components by exploiting insecure network protocols.
  3. DDoS Attack: Attackers flood the network with traffic, overwhelming the infrastructure and causing service outages.
  4. Insecure Protocols: An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in outdated or insecure network protocols to compromise data integrity and confidentiality.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Auto Scaling data at rest and in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data related to AWS Auto Scaling, including configuration files and logs, is encrypted both at rest and in transit using AWS encryption services.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Store configuration files in S3 or EFS with server-side encryption using AWS KMS.
  • Encrypt CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs using AWS KMS.

Encrypt Data in Transit:

  • Use HTTPS (TLS) for data transmission.

Manage Access:

  • Apply IAM policies for least privilege access to encryption keys.

Monitor Compliance:

  • Use AWS Config to ensure encryption policies are followed.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement service-linked roles for Auto Scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Implement service-linked roles for AWS Auto Scaling to provide permissions for AWS services to perform actions on your behalf securely. This ensures that Auto Scaling can function properly while adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Create Service-Linked Role:

  • Use the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK to create a service-linked role specifically for Auto Scaling.
  • The role is predefined with the necessary permissions for Auto Scaling to operate securely.

Assign Service-Linked Role:

  • Ensure that the Auto Scaling service is using the created service-linked role to perform its operations.

Review Role Permissions:

  • Regularly review the permissions assigned to the service-linked role to ensure they are up to date and adhere to security best practices.

Monitor Role Activity:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log the activities performed by the service-linked role for auditing and compliance purposes.

By following these steps, you can securely delegate necessary permissions to AWS Auto Scaling while maintaining tight security controls.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Restrict traffic with security groups for Auto Scaling instances
countermeasure.desc:
Configure security groups to restrict traffic to and from AWS Auto Scaling instances, allowing only necessary ports and protocols. This enhances security by limiting exposure to potential threats.

Create Security Groups:

  • Define security groups specifically for Auto Scaling instances.

Restrict Inbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary inbound ports and protocols (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS for web servers, SSH for management).
  • Specify trusted IP ranges for access where applicable.

Restrict Outbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary outbound ports and protocols required for instance functionality.

Regularly Review and Update Rules:

  • Periodically audit security group rules to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege.
  • Adjust rules as necessary based on changes in application requirements or security policies.

countermeasure.name: Test scaling policies in staging environment
countermeasure.desc:
Test all AWS Auto Scaling policies in a staging environment before deploying them to production. This ensures their effectiveness and stability, minimizing the risk of configuration errors that could impact application performance and availability.

Set Up Staging Environment:

  • Mirror the production environment in staging to accurately test scaling policies.

Deploy and Test:

  • Implement scaling policies in the staging environment.
  • Conduct load tests and monitor the behavior of the scaling policies under various scenarios.

Review and Adjust:

  • Analyze test results and adjust policies as necessary to ensure optimal performance and stability.

Deploy to Production:

  • Once verified, apply the tested and adjusted scaling policies to the production environment.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Auto Scaling resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to AWS Auto Scaling resources can result in unintended changes to scaling policies, unauthorized scaling actions, and potential misuse of resources, leading to performance issues and security breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM credentials
    • Misconfigured IAM roles and policies
    • Exploiting application vulnerabilities
    • Lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA)

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive configuration data
  • Operational Disruption: Service performance issues
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to unauthorized scaling actions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen AWS credentials to modify Auto Scaling policies, leading to resource misuse.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Roles: Broad permissions in IAM roles allow unauthorized changes to Auto Scaling settings.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee alters scaling policies to disrupt services.
  4. Application Exploitation: Exploiting a vulnerability to gain elevated permissions and change Auto Scaling configurations.

Implementing strict IAM policies, enabling MFA, regularly auditing roles, and monitoring activities can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breaches due to insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Data breaches due to insufficient data protection in AWS Auto Scaling involve unauthorized access to sensitive data because of inadequate encryption, misconfiguration, or weak data handling practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted data at rest or in transit
    • Misconfigured storage settings
    • Exploitation of weak access controls
    • Insufficient data handling practices

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Exposure of sensitive data, such as customer information or proprietary business data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized modification of data
  • Operational Disruption: Service interruptions and loss of data integrity
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Potential fines and legal action due to failure to comply with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage: An attacker gains access to unencrypted storage containing sensitive data, leading to data theft.
  2. Misconfigured Permissions: Improper configuration of S3 bucket permissions results in public access to sensitive data.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee with access to sensitive data exports it without proper authorization.
  4. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data in transit due to lack of encryption, gaining access to sensitive information.

Implementing data encryption, configuring storage settings securely, enforcing strict access controls, and following best practices for data handling can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Misconfiguration of AWS Auto Scaling policies can lead to improper scaling actions, resulting in over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources. This can negatively impact application performance, availability, and cost efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Developers, DevOps engineers, external attackers (through compromised accounts)
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Incorrect scaling thresholds and metrics
    • Overly aggressive or conservative scaling policies
    • Manual errors during policy configuration
    • Lack of testing and validation for scaling policies

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning leads to unnecessary costs, while under-provisioning causes performance degradation.
  • Operational Disruption: Unstable application performance and potential downtime.
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to inefficient resource scaling.
  • Reputation Damage: Customer dissatisfaction due to poor application performance and reliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Thresholds: A developer sets CPU utilization thresholds too low, causing Auto Scaling to add more instances than necessary, leading to high costs.
  2. Overly Aggressive Scaling: An overly aggressive scaling policy scales up resources too quickly in response to minor traffic spikes, resulting in resource waste.
  3. Lack of Testing: A misconfigured scaling policy is applied directly to production without testing, leading to unexpected behavior and service disruptions.
  4. Manual Configuration Errors: An engineer manually configures a scaling policy with incorrect parameters, causing the application to scale inadequately during peak load.

By implementing these countermeasures, you can mitigate the risks associated with misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies and ensure that your application scales efficiently and cost-effectively.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Network vulnerabilities in AWS Auto Scaling involve weaknesses in the network configuration that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access, disrupt services, or exfiltrate data. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper network segmentation, insecure protocols, or misconfigured network security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of open ports and services
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks
    • DDoS attacks targeting network infrastructure
    • Exploiting insecure network protocols

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive data and resources
  • Data Breach: Exposure of confidential information
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degraded performance due to network attacks
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to perceived security weaknesses
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with mitigating breaches and service disruptions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Ports: An attacker scans for and exploits open ports on Auto Scaling instances, gaining unauthorized access to the network.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts and alters communications between Auto Scaling components by exploiting insecure network protocols.
  3. DDoS Attack: Attackers flood the network with traffic, overwhelming the infrastructure and causing service outages.
  4. Insecure Protocols: An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in outdated or insecure network protocols to compromise data integrity and confidentiality.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to AWS Auto Scaling resources can result in unintended changes to scaling policies, unauthorized scaling actions, and potential misuse of resources, leading to performance issues and security breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM credentials
    • Misconfigured IAM roles and policies
    • Exploiting application vulnerabilities
    • Lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA)

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive configuration data
  • Operational Disruption: Service performance issues
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to unauthorized scaling actions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen AWS credentials to modify Auto Scaling policies, leading to resource misuse.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Roles: Broad permissions in IAM roles allow unauthorized changes to Auto Scaling settings.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee alters scaling policies to disrupt services.
  4. Application Exploitation: Exploiting a vulnerability to gain elevated permissions and change Auto Scaling configurations.

Implementing strict IAM policies, enabling MFA, regularly auditing roles, and monitoring activities can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breaches due to insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Data breaches due to insufficient data protection in AWS Auto Scaling involve unauthorized access to sensitive data because of inadequate encryption, misconfiguration, or weak data handling practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted data at rest or in transit
    • Misconfigured storage settings
    • Exploitation of weak access controls
    • Insufficient data handling practices

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Exposure of sensitive data, such as customer information or proprietary business data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized modification of data
  • Operational Disruption: Service interruptions and loss of data integrity
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Potential fines and legal action due to failure to comply with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage: An attacker gains access to unencrypted storage containing sensitive data, leading to data theft.
  2. Misconfigured Permissions: Improper configuration of S3 bucket permissions results in public access to sensitive data.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee with access to sensitive data exports it without proper authorization.
  4. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data in transit due to lack of encryption, gaining access to sensitive information.

Implementing data encryption, configuring storage settings securely, enforcing strict access controls, and following best practices for data handling can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Network vulnerabilities in AWS Auto Scaling involve weaknesses in the network configuration that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access, disrupt services, or exfiltrate data. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper network segmentation, insecure protocols, or misconfigured network security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of open ports and services
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks
    • DDoS attacks targeting network infrastructure
    • Exploiting insecure network protocols

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive data and resources
  • Data Breach: Exposure of confidential information
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degraded performance due to network attacks
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to perceived security weaknesses
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with mitigating breaches and service disruptions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Ports: An attacker scans for and exploits open ports on Auto Scaling instances, gaining unauthorized access to the network.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts and alters communications between Auto Scaling components by exploiting insecure network protocols.
  3. DDoS Attack: Attackers flood the network with traffic, overwhelming the infrastructure and causing service outages.
  4. Insecure Protocols: An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in outdated or insecure network protocols to compromise data integrity and confidentiality.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Misconfiguration of AWS Auto Scaling policies can lead to improper scaling actions, resulting in over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources. This can negatively impact application performance, availability, and cost efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Developers, DevOps engineers, external attackers (through compromised accounts)
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Incorrect scaling thresholds and metrics
    • Overly aggressive or conservative scaling policies
    • Manual errors during policy configuration
    • Lack of testing and validation for scaling policies

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning leads to unnecessary costs, while under-provisioning causes performance degradation.
  • Operational Disruption: Unstable application performance and potential downtime.
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to inefficient resource scaling.
  • Reputation Damage: Customer dissatisfaction due to poor application performance and reliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Thresholds: A developer sets CPU utilization thresholds too low, causing Auto Scaling to add more instances than necessary, leading to high costs.
  2. Overly Aggressive Scaling: An overly aggressive scaling policy scales up resources too quickly in response to minor traffic spikes, resulting in resource waste.
  3. Lack of Testing: A misconfigured scaling policy is applied directly to production without testing, leading to unexpected behavior and service disruptions.
  4. Manual Configuration Errors: An engineer manually configures a scaling policy with incorrect parameters, causing the application to scale inadequately during peak load.

By implementing these countermeasures, you can mitigate the risks associated with misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies and ensure that your application scales efficiently and cost-effectively.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Auto Scaling data at rest and in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data related to AWS Auto Scaling, including configuration files and logs, is encrypted both at rest and in transit using AWS encryption services.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Store configuration files in S3 or EFS with server-side encryption using AWS KMS.
  • Encrypt CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs using AWS KMS.

Encrypt Data in Transit:

  • Use HTTPS (TLS) for data transmission.

Manage Access:

  • Apply IAM policies for least privilege access to encryption keys.

Monitor Compliance:

  • Use AWS Config to ensure encryption policies are followed.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement service-linked roles for Auto Scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Implement service-linked roles for AWS Auto Scaling to provide permissions for AWS services to perform actions on your behalf securely. This ensures that Auto Scaling can function properly while adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Create Service-Linked Role:

  • Use the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK to create a service-linked role specifically for Auto Scaling.
  • The role is predefined with the necessary permissions for Auto Scaling to operate securely.

Assign Service-Linked Role:

  • Ensure that the Auto Scaling service is using the created service-linked role to perform its operations.

Review Role Permissions:

  • Regularly review the permissions assigned to the service-linked role to ensure they are up to date and adhere to security best practices.

Monitor Role Activity:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log the activities performed by the service-linked role for auditing and compliance purposes.

By following these steps, you can securely delegate necessary permissions to AWS Auto Scaling while maintaining tight security controls.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Restrict traffic with security groups for Auto Scaling instances
countermeasure.desc:
Configure security groups to restrict traffic to and from AWS Auto Scaling instances, allowing only necessary ports and protocols. This enhances security by limiting exposure to potential threats.

Create Security Groups:

  • Define security groups specifically for Auto Scaling instances.

Restrict Inbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary inbound ports and protocols (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS for web servers, SSH for management).
  • Specify trusted IP ranges for access where applicable.

Restrict Outbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary outbound ports and protocols required for instance functionality.

Regularly Review and Update Rules:

  • Periodically audit security group rules to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege.
  • Adjust rules as necessary based on changes in application requirements or security policies.

reference.name: Identity and Access Management for Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Test scaling policies in staging environment
countermeasure.desc:
Test all AWS Auto Scaling policies in a staging environment before deploying them to production. This ensures their effectiveness and stability, minimizing the risk of configuration errors that could impact application performance and availability.

Set Up Staging Environment:

  • Mirror the production environment in staging to accurately test scaling policies.

Deploy and Test:

  • Implement scaling policies in the staging environment.
  • Conduct load tests and monitor the behavior of the scaling policies under various scenarios.

Review and Adjust:

  • Analyze test results and adjust policies as necessary to ensure optimal performance and stability.

Deploy to Production:

  • Once verified, apply the tested and adjusted scaling policies to the production environment.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Auto Scaling data at rest and in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data related to AWS Auto Scaling, including configuration files and logs, is encrypted both at rest and in transit using AWS encryption services.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Store configuration files in S3 or EFS with server-side encryption using AWS KMS.
  • Encrypt CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs using AWS KMS.

Encrypt Data in Transit:

  • Use HTTPS (TLS) for data transmission.

Manage Access:

  • Apply IAM policies for least privilege access to encryption keys.

Monitor Compliance:

  • Use AWS Config to ensure encryption policies are followed.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement service-linked roles for Auto Scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Implement service-linked roles for AWS Auto Scaling to provide permissions for AWS services to perform actions on your behalf securely. This ensures that Auto Scaling can function properly while adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Create Service-Linked Role:

  • Use the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK to create a service-linked role specifically for Auto Scaling.
  • The role is predefined with the necessary permissions for Auto Scaling to operate securely.

Assign Service-Linked Role:

  • Ensure that the Auto Scaling service is using the created service-linked role to perform its operations.

Review Role Permissions:

  • Regularly review the permissions assigned to the service-linked role to ensure they are up to date and adhere to security best practices.

Monitor Role Activity:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log the activities performed by the service-linked role for auditing and compliance purposes.

By following these steps, you can securely delegate necessary permissions to AWS Auto Scaling while maintaining tight security controls.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Restrict traffic with security groups for Auto Scaling instances
countermeasure.desc:
Configure security groups to restrict traffic to and from AWS Auto Scaling instances, allowing only necessary ports and protocols. This enhances security by limiting exposure to potential threats.

Create Security Groups:

  • Define security groups specifically for Auto Scaling instances.

Restrict Inbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary inbound ports and protocols (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS for web servers, SSH for management).
  • Specify trusted IP ranges for access where applicable.

Restrict Outbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary outbound ports and protocols required for instance functionality.

Regularly Review and Update Rules:

  • Periodically audit security group rules to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege.
  • Adjust rules as necessary based on changes in application requirements or security policies.

countermeasure.name: Test scaling policies in staging environment
countermeasure.desc:
Test all AWS Auto Scaling policies in a staging environment before deploying them to production. This ensures their effectiveness and stability, minimizing the risk of configuration errors that could impact application performance and availability.

Set Up Staging Environment:

  • Mirror the production environment in staging to accurately test scaling policies.

Deploy and Test:

  • Implement scaling policies in the staging environment.
  • Conduct load tests and monitor the behavior of the scaling policies under various scenarios.

Review and Adjust:

  • Analyze test results and adjust policies as necessary to ensure optimal performance and stability.

Deploy to Production:

  • Once verified, apply the tested and adjusted scaling policies to the production environment.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Auto Scaling resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to AWS Auto Scaling resources can result in unintended changes to scaling policies, unauthorized scaling actions, and potential misuse of resources, leading to performance issues and security breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM credentials
    • Misconfigured IAM roles and policies
    • Exploiting application vulnerabilities
    • Lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA)

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive configuration data
  • Operational Disruption: Service performance issues
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to unauthorized scaling actions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen AWS credentials to modify Auto Scaling policies, leading to resource misuse.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Roles: Broad permissions in IAM roles allow unauthorized changes to Auto Scaling settings.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee alters scaling policies to disrupt services.
  4. Application Exploitation: Exploiting a vulnerability to gain elevated permissions and change Auto Scaling configurations.

Implementing strict IAM policies, enabling MFA, regularly auditing roles, and monitoring activities can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breaches due to insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Data breaches due to insufficient data protection in AWS Auto Scaling involve unauthorized access to sensitive data because of inadequate encryption, misconfiguration, or weak data handling practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted data at rest or in transit
    • Misconfigured storage settings
    • Exploitation of weak access controls
    • Insufficient data handling practices

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Exposure of sensitive data, such as customer information or proprietary business data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized modification of data
  • Operational Disruption: Service interruptions and loss of data integrity
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Potential fines and legal action due to failure to comply with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage: An attacker gains access to unencrypted storage containing sensitive data, leading to data theft.
  2. Misconfigured Permissions: Improper configuration of S3 bucket permissions results in public access to sensitive data.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee with access to sensitive data exports it without proper authorization.
  4. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data in transit due to lack of encryption, gaining access to sensitive information.

Implementing data encryption, configuring storage settings securely, enforcing strict access controls, and following best practices for data handling can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Misconfiguration of AWS Auto Scaling policies can lead to improper scaling actions, resulting in over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources. This can negatively impact application performance, availability, and cost efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Developers, DevOps engineers, external attackers (through compromised accounts)
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Incorrect scaling thresholds and metrics
    • Overly aggressive or conservative scaling policies
    • Manual errors during policy configuration
    • Lack of testing and validation for scaling policies

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning leads to unnecessary costs, while under-provisioning causes performance degradation.
  • Operational Disruption: Unstable application performance and potential downtime.
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to inefficient resource scaling.
  • Reputation Damage: Customer dissatisfaction due to poor application performance and reliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Thresholds: A developer sets CPU utilization thresholds too low, causing Auto Scaling to add more instances than necessary, leading to high costs.
  2. Overly Aggressive Scaling: An overly aggressive scaling policy scales up resources too quickly in response to minor traffic spikes, resulting in resource waste.
  3. Lack of Testing: A misconfigured scaling policy is applied directly to production without testing, leading to unexpected behavior and service disruptions.
  4. Manual Configuration Errors: An engineer manually configures a scaling policy with incorrect parameters, causing the application to scale inadequately during peak load.

By implementing these countermeasures, you can mitigate the risks associated with misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies and ensure that your application scales efficiently and cost-effectively.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Network vulnerabilities in AWS Auto Scaling involve weaknesses in the network configuration that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access, disrupt services, or exfiltrate data. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper network segmentation, insecure protocols, or misconfigured network security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of open ports and services
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks
    • DDoS attacks targeting network infrastructure
    • Exploiting insecure network protocols

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive data and resources
  • Data Breach: Exposure of confidential information
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degraded performance due to network attacks
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to perceived security weaknesses
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with mitigating breaches and service disruptions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Ports: An attacker scans for and exploits open ports on Auto Scaling instances, gaining unauthorized access to the network.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts and alters communications between Auto Scaling components by exploiting insecure network protocols.
  3. DDoS Attack: Attackers flood the network with traffic, overwhelming the infrastructure and causing service outages.
  4. Insecure Protocols: An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in outdated or insecure network protocols to compromise data integrity and confidentiality.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

countermeasure.name: Configure public IP addresses only for necessary ELBs
countermeasure.desc: Only configure public IP addresses on Elastic Load Balancers (ELBs) that need to accept incoming requests from outside the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). This minimizes exposure to the internet and reduces the risk of unauthorized access. To implement this, ensure that ELBs without the requirement for public access are assigned private IP addresses. For ELBs requiring public access, carefully review and restrict the associated security group rules to allow only necessary traffic. Regularly audit and validate the configuration to maintain compliance with security best practices.

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Define network ACLs to control access to the VPC
countermeasure.desc: Define network Access Control Lists (ACLs) to control access to your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). Network ACLs provide an additional layer of security by acting as a stateless firewall for controlling inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level. To implement this, create custom network ACLs with specific rules to allow or deny traffic based on protocol, port number, and source/destination IP addresses. Apply these ACLs to your VPC subnets to enforce stringent access controls and protect your resources from unauthorized access.

reference.name: Control subnet traffic with network access control lists

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Define security groups to control access to AWS resources
countermeasure.desc: Define security groups to control access to AWS resources. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify rules that permit or deny inbound and outbound traffic to and from your resources. To implement this, create security groups with specific rules that allow only necessary traffic based on protocol, port number, and source/destination IP addresses. Apply these security groups to your AWS resources, such as EC2 instances and ELBs, to enforce stringent access controls and enhance security.

reference.name: Security in Elastic Load Balancing

standard.ref: Information security for use of cloud services
Infrastructure and Virtualization Security Policy and Procedures
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(7)
SC-50 Software-enforced Separation and Policy Enforcement
Separation of development, test and production environments

countermeasure.name: Enable authentication on ALB listeners to validate incoming requests
countermeasure.desc: Enable authentication on Application Load Balancer (ALB) listeners to validate all incoming requests and offload the authentication burden from the application. This ensures that only authenticated users can access your services, enhancing security and reducing the load on backend applications. To implement this, configure the ALB to use an authentication provider such as Amazon Cognito or a third-party provider via OpenID Connect. Set up authentication rules in the ALB listener settings to enforce user authentication before allowing access to the target application.

reference.name: Authenticate users using an Application Load Balancer

countermeasure.name: Enable Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) for ELB
countermeasure.desc: Enable Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) for AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to ensure that session keys cannot be compromised even if the server's long-term key is. PFS enhances the security of encrypted communications by generating unique session keys for each connection, preventing the decryption of past sessions in the event of key compromise. To implement this, configure your ELB to use TLS cipher suites that support PFS, such as those using Diffie-Hellman key exchange. Regularly review and update your cipher suite configurations to maintain strong encryption standards.

reference.name: Security in Elastic Load Balancing

countermeasure.name: Ensure encrypted communication for ELB listeners
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that listeners on the AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) support and require encrypted communication using TLS or HTTPS. This guarantees that data transmitted between clients and the load balancer is secure. To implement this, configure your ELB to use TLS/HTTPS listeners by creating and uploading an SSL/TLS certificate in AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) and then attaching the certificate to the ELB listener. Update your application settings to only accept secure connections.

reference.name: Data protection in Elastic Load Balancing

countermeasure.name: Restrict port and IP address ranges as much as possible
countermeasure.desc: Restrict port and IP address ranges as much as possible to minimize the attack surface and enhance the security of your AWS resources. This involves configuring security groups and network ACLs to allow only the necessary ports and specific IP ranges required for your application to function. By limiting the open ports and allowed IP addresses, you reduce the risk of unauthorized access and potential exploitation of vulnerabilities. Regularly review and update these rules to ensure they align with the current security requirements.

This enhances security by filtering out malicious traffic and reducing the risk of attacks. To implement this, configure AWS WAF with rules that specify allowed and blocked IP ranges, define geo-location restrictions, and create custom conditions based on your security requirements. Associate the WAF with your ELB to enforce these rules and monitor the traffic for compliance and potential threats. Regularly update and review the rules to maintain effective protection.

countermeasure.desc: To enhance security for AWS Elastic Load Balancing (ELB), configure and use interface endpoints to securely access the ELB from within your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). This ensures that all communication between the ELB and its clients remains within the AWS network, reducing exposure to the internet and minimizing the risk of unauthorized access. To implement this, create an interface VPC endpoint for ELB, configure your routing tables, and update security group rules to allow traffic from the endpoint.
