usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single Availability Zone dependency causing regional service outage impact
threat.desc:
General threat description
Workloads located in a single AWS Availability Zone are exposed to disruptions resulting from zonal failures, scheduled maintenance, or capacity constraints, posing risks to service continuity and data accessibility.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Zonal failures may arise from natural disasters, hardware malfunctions, or network issues. Planned maintenance or sudden demand spikes may also contribute to decreased availability.
Impacts
The impacts include potential outages, temporary or permanent loss of data, degradation of application performance, and loss of trust or revenue resulting from service disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hardware failure within an Availability Zone causes a widespread outage, bringing down critical applications hosted in that zone. Alternatively, a planned maintenance event reduces resource availability, resulting in service degradation for all workloads relying exclusively on that zone.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Availability Zone identifier mismatch across accounts causing misplacement
threat.desc:
General threat description
Hardcoding the names of Availability Zones can lead to resources being placed in unintended physical zones due to the variability in how names map to physical zones across accounts, which can compromise redundancy and failover strategies.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unintentional misconfiguration by developers or operators, reliance on incorrect documentation, or automated deployment scripts that do not account for differing zone mappings.
Impacts
Potential lack of high availability, increased risk of resource failure in disasters, and compromised system reliability due to violated redundancy and failover assumptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A developer deploys instances to us-east-1a, assuming it corresponds to a specific physical zone across all accounts, but the mapping differs in their organizations AWS account, placing resources in the same physical zone as other critical systems. A failure in this zone leads to a cascading outage.

threat.name: Capacity and placement risk within an Availability Zone
threat.desc:
General threat description
Zonal capacity constraints or inflexible placement strategies can restrict the ability to scale or perform failovers during disruptions, leading to system downtime or reduced service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigurations, resource limitations, or improper distribution of workloads can exacerbate zonal constraints and lack of effective placement mechanisms.
Impacts
Reduced service availability, inability to recover from disruptions, and potential customer dissatisfaction due to reliability issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
A sudden increase in resource demand overwhelms a specific Availability Zone, and the inability to migrate workloads to another zone results in degraded performance or service outages. Alternatively, rigid placement strategies restrict scalability, preventing efficient allocation of resources across zones during high loads.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Subnet and route misconfiguration exposing Availability Zone resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) design can lead to unintended exposure of instances or services within an Availability Zone to networks or the internet, compromising isolation and security.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit shared route tables, misconfigured public subnets meant to be private, or overly permissive network ACLs to gain unauthorized access or disrupt services.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, unauthorized access, service disruptions, or exploitation of exposed resources for malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization accidentally configures a public subnet instead of a private one, inadvertently exposing critical services to the internet. Attackers notice and exploit misconfigured ACLs to access sensitive data or disrupt internal services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Cross-Availability Zone traffic exposure due to broad network rules
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overly permissive configurations in security groups or network ACLs can inadvertently create unintended cross-Availability Zone access paths, potentially increasing the impact of a compromise and expanding the blast radius.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or misconfigured resources can exploit permissive settings to traverse networks across zones, accessing unauthorized systems or data in other Availability Zones.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and escalation of security incidents across multiple zones, reducing the isolation benefits of Availability Zones.
Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured database in one zone with an overly permissive security group gets exploited by an attacker, who then pivots to access sensitive systems in other zones through unintended network paths, amplifying the impact of the event.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Uncontrolled internet egress from Availability Zone subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Instances in private subnets of an Availability Zone may inadvertently access the internet through shared NAT gateways or misconfigured routing, potentially exposing them to risks such as data exfiltration or unauthorized command-and-control activities if outbound traffic is not strictly controlled per zone.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured routing tables, overly permissive NAT gateway rules, or unmonitored outbound traffic within the private subnets to establish unauthorized communication channels with external entities.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized remote control of instances, or exploitation of the infrastructure for malicious activity, which could lead to financial, reputational, and operational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might exploit a misconfigured routing table to redirect traffic from instances to a malicious server on the internet, extracting sensitive information. Alternatively, compromised instances could use a shared NAT gateway to contact a command-and-control server, initiating further attacks or lateral movement within the environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient Availability Zone-aware logging and visibility
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient logging and monitoring granularity associated with Availability Zones can hinder prompt identification and management of zonal faults, unauthorized lateral movement, or configuration errors, weakening the efficacy of incident response.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploiting gaps in logging to move laterally between zones or leveraging undetected misconfigurations to compromise security.
Impacts
Delayed detection of security concerns, reduced incident response times, and increased potential for extensive damage or data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An undetected misconfiguration in one zone allows unauthorized access, and the lack of granular monitoring enables an attacker to move laterally to compromise other zones without being noticed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-349
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-349: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data The product, when processing trusted data, accepts any untrusted data that is also included with the trusted data, treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-358
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-358: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard The product does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm, protocol, or technique.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-408
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-408: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Amplification The product allows an entity to perform a legitimate but expensive operation before authentication or authorization has taken place.

weakness.name: CWE-663
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-663: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

weakness.name: CWE-697
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-697: Incorrect Comparison The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-710
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-710: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards The product does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to resultant weaknesses or increase the severity of the associated vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Apply least-privilege stateful security group rules
countermeasure.desc:
Define inbound and outbound security-group (SG) rules so that every AWS workload can send or receive traffic only on the protocols and ports it actually uses, nothing more. Because SGs are statefulreturn traffic is automatically allowedyou do not need mirror rules; focus on the direction that initiates the flow.

Implementation guidance

  1. Map the traffic flows for each component (for Route 53 Resolver endpoints that means UDP/TCP 53, for web apps TCP 80/443, etc.).
  2. Create one SG per role (e.g., resolver-inbound, web-front, db-backend).
  3. Ingress rules
    • Allow only the required protocol/port combination from the smallest possible CIDR or, preferably, from another SG (for east-west traffic).
    • Block 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0 unless there is a documented business reason.
  4. Egress rules
    • Remove the default allow all; add explicit destinations and ports (for example, TCP 443 to a patch repository).
    • Remember: responses to permitted ingress traffic do not need additional egress rules thanks to SG statefulness.
  5. Automation & guardrails
    • Bake SGs into CloudFormation/Terraform modules; lint templates for wild-card CIDRs or open ports.
    • Enable AWS Config managed rules such as restricted-common-ports or custom rules that fail a build when an SG exposes SSH/RDP/DB ports to the internet.
    • Use VPC Flow Logs and Reachability Analyzer to validate that only intended paths succeed.
  6. Continuous review
    • Periodically audit SGs with Security Hub; prune stale or unused rules.
    • When requirements change (for example, adding DNS over TLS on port 853), update the SGs in IaC first, then deploy.

Following a least-privilege, stateful-aware model minimizes the attack surface, avoids duplicate rules, and keeps network intent clear and enforceable.

references

  • Security groups connection tracking
  • Restrict incoming traffic to only authorized ports AWS Prescriptive Guidance

countermeasure.name: Create inbound Resolver endpoints across multiple AZs
countermeasure.desc:
Provision every Route 53 Resolver inbound endpoint with at least two IP addresses, each in a different Availability Zone (AZ) of the VPC. Route 53 maps every IP to an elastic network interface (ENI), so distributing them across AZ-scoped subnets ensures that DNS resolution continues even if an AZ, subnet, or ENI is impaired.

Implementation checklist

  1. Subnet planning Identify two or more private subnets in distinct AZs that have outbound routes to your on-premises network (via Direct Connect or VPN).
  2. Endpoint creation In the Route 53 console, choose Inbound endpoints Create inbound endpoint, then add one IP per chosen subnet. Repeat until you have a minimum of two IP addresses.
  3. Security groups Attach a security group that allows inbound UDP/TCP 53 from the IP ranges of your on-premises DNS resolvers.
  4. Forwarding configuration Configure each on-premises resolver to forward queries to all endpoint IPs (round-robin or equal-cost) so fail-over happens automatically.
  5. Monitoring & drift control
    • Enable Route 53 Resolver query logging and CloudWatch metrics (e.g., DnsQueries, DnsResolverEndpointMetricName).
    • Deploy an AWS Config rule or IaC linter that fails if an inbound endpoint has fewer than two IPs or all IPs reside in one AZ.
  6. Capacity events & maintenance Add a third IP (in a third AZ if available) when traffic or resiliency requirements grow; remove only after confirming redundancy.

Following this pattern eliminates the single-AZ single-ENI failure mode and aligns with AWS best-practice guidance for high-availability DNS ingress.

references

  • High availability for Resolver endpoints Amazon Route 53 Developer Guide
  • Best practices for Resolver Amazon Route 53 Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Define default record in each geolocation, geoproximity, and latency policy
countermeasure.desc:
For every Route 53 record set that uses geolocation, geoproximity, or latency-based routing, create a catch-all (default) record so that any query that doesnt match a specific location, bias shape, or Region still receives a valid answer instead of a NOERROR NODATA response.

Implementation steps

  1. Geolocation records Add one extra record whose Location is set to Default. This record answers:
    • IP addresses that Route 53 cannot map to a geography.
    • Countries, continents, or subdivisions for which you have not created explicit records.
  2. Geoproximity records Create a record that covers the entire globe by leaving the bias at 0 and not restricting the AWS Region or endpoint. (Alternatively, add a parallel simple record with the same name to act as the fallback.)
  3. Latency-based records Include at least one latency record that points to a universally acceptable Region (for example, the Region hosting your primary stack). If all health-checked latency records become UNHEALTHY, pair the default record with a failover standby or a health check that keeps it available.
  4. Validation Use dig +trace or Resolver Query Logging to confirm that queries from out-of-scope locations resolve to the default answer.
  5. Automation & drift detection Add a CI/CD test or AWS Config custom rule that fails a deployment if an advanced routing set (geo*, latency) lacks at least one default record. Review routing policies quarterly as new Regions or markets go live.

Having a default record guarantees that every DNS question receives an authoritative response, preventing unnecessary retransmits, resolver fall-back to TCP, and user-visible outages.

references

  • Geolocation routing
  • Values specific for geolocation records

countermeasure.name: Delegate subdomains from the immediate parent hosted zone
countermeasure.desc:
For every subdomain that you manage in Amazon Route 53, create a dedicated hosted zone for that subdomain and publish an NS record set in the parent hosted zone that points to the name servers assigned to the child zone. Never skip a level (for example, delegate api.dev.example.com directly from example.com); each child zone must be delegated by its immediate parent to guarantee that recursive resolvers can follow the hierarchy without ambiguity or cache inconsistencies.

Implementation steps

  1. Create the child hosted zone (e.g., dev.example.com) and note the four authoritative name-server values that Route 53 returns.
  2. In the parent hosted zone (e.g., example.com), add an NS record named exactly like the subdomain ( dev.example.com ) that lists those four name servers. Keep the TTL short (300 s900 s) while you validate, then raise it when stable.
  3. (Optional but recommended) add a matching SOA record in the child zone to aid debugging and DNSSEC deployments.
  4. Enforce the rule in infrastructure-as-code: have a linter or CI/CD test that fails if a hosted zones domain cannot be found as an NS record in its parent.
  5. Monitor with Route 53 Resolver Query Logging or a custom AWS Config rule to alert on missing or mismatched NS delegations.

Correct, explicit delegation at each level ensures consistent name resolution, avoids ghost zones that some resolvers cache, and lets you move subdomain ownership or accounts safely without touching the apex domain.

references

  • Routing traffic for subdomains
  • Best practices for Amazon Route 53

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive health check strategy
countermeasure.desc:
Create an Amazon Route 53 health-monitoring stack that automatically detects outages, triggers alerts, and shifts traffic away from unhealthy endpoints:

  1. Stable targets. Point each health check at an Elastic IP (EIP) or other static address (for ALB/NLB use their DNS name) so the target doesnt change when an instance is replaced. Deleteor re-pointchecks whenever the underlying resource is retired.
  2. Intervals & thresholds.
    • Start with the 30 s default; reduce to 10 s for customer-facing or transactional services that require rapid failover.
    • Set the failure threshold to 35 consecutive probes; decrease (12) for aggressive failover or increase (610) if flapping is a concern.
  3. Multi-region checkers. Enable Evaluate target health in multiple regions so that decisions arent skewed by a single checker outage.
  4. CloudWatch integration. Route 53 publishes a HealthCheckStatus metric for every check. Create a CloudWatch alarm that fires when the status equals 0 for 1 datapoint, and wire it to an SNS topic, PagerDuty, or Slack webhook.
  5. Routing & failover policies.
    • Attach the health check to the primary DNS record in a Failover or Multivalue routing policy.
    • Define one or more standby records (different EIP, Region, or AWS account) that become authoritative when the primary is marked UNHEALTHY. Validate that clients resolve the standby within your records TTL.
  6. Continuous monitoring.
    • Enable Route 53 query logging and review CloudWatch metrics weekly; look for rising latency or sporadic failures.
    • Schedule a quarterly runbook review: verify EIPs are current, intervals/thresholds match SLOs, alarms reach the right on-call rotation, and failover actually occurs during a game-day test.
  7. Guardrails & automation.
    • Store health checks, alarms, and DNS records in CloudFormation/Terraform modules.
    • Add a CI/CD lint rule (or AWS Config custom rule) that fails a build if a health check:
      • Lacks an alarm,
      • Uses an interval > 30 s for a critical service, or
      • Evaluates in fewer than two AWS regions.

Following these steps ensures that health monitoring is consistent, fast, and actionable, while automatic DNS failover keeps endpoints available during incidents.

References

  • Best practices for Amazon Route 53 health checks
  • Monitoring health checks with CloudWatch Route 53 Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Monitor abnormal DNS query patterns and escalate potential zone-walking
countermeasure.desc:
Enable continuous visibility into the DNS traffic that Amazon Route 53 handles for your accounts and take action when activity suggests a zone-walking attack (rapid, exhaustive queries across a zone that trigger Resolver throttling):

  1. Capture the data
    • Turn on Route 53 Resolver query logging (or public-hosted-zone query logging) and stream logs to CloudWatch Logs, S3, or Firehose for retention and analysis.
    • Track CloudWatch metrics such as DNSQueries, DnsResolverQueries, and (for Resolver endpoints) ConnectionTrackingDroppedQueries.
  2. Baseline normal behaviour
    • Use CloudWatch Metric Math or Anomaly Detection to learn typical query-per-second (QPS) levels and NXDOMAIN ratios for each hosted zone or VPC.
    • Flag sudden spikes, a surge in unique subdomain labels, or high NXDOMAIN countscommon signatures of enumeration tools.
  3. Alert on suspected attacks
    • Create metric filters or Lambda log analytics that detect:
      • X % NXDOMAIN or SERVFAIL responses over Y minutes.
      • Sequential queries that iterate through the alphabet or numeric ranges.
      • Resolver logs showing THROTTLED responses.
    • Wire alarms to an on-call channel (SNS PagerDuty/Slack) so investigation starts immediately.
  4. Escalate when throttling appears
    • If queries begin timing out and logs show throttling yet the traffic is legitimate, open an AWS Support case citing the affected Resolver endpoint IDs and timestamps. The Route 53 team can confirm throttling heuristics and restore capacity if appropriate.
  5. Harden and review
    • Apply DNS Firewall rules or upstream ACLs to block abusive source ranges.
    • Review baselines and alarm thresholds quarterly; update detection logic as traffic patterns evolve.

Following this workflow ensures that potential zone-walking attempts are detected quickly, legitimate traffic is restored, and AWS is engaged when throttling impacts availability.

References:

  • DNS zone walking

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Poll GetChange until change is INSYNC before next deployment step
countermeasure.desc:
When your pipeline submits a ChangeResourceRecordSets, ChangeTagsForResource, or CreateHostedZone request, Route 53 returns a change ID. Automate a loop that calls GetChange <change-id> every few seconds and proceeds only when the response field Status == INSYNC. This guarantees that the update has propagated to every Route 53 authoritative name server before later stagessuch as health checks, load-balancer swaps, or traffic-shift testsrun.

Implementation tips

  1. Loop with back-off

    1. while true; do
       status=$(aws route53 get-change --id "$CHANGE_ID" --query 'ChangeInfo.Status' --output text)
       [ "$status" = "INSYNC" ] && break
       sleep 5   # or exponential back-off capped at 30 s
      done 

    In IaC tools (CloudFormation, Terraform) or CD frameworks (CodePipeline, GitHub Actions), wrap the check in a retry helper so failures surface clearly.

  2. Timeout and alerting
    • Set a max wait (e.g., 5 min); raise an alarm or fail the job if the change never becomes INSYNC.
    • Send the failure to an on-call channel via SNS so someone can investigate Route 53 control-plane health.
  3. Parallelism
    If you batch multiple changes, store each change ID and poll them in parallel to shorten overall deploy time, but make sure all return INSYNC before continuing.
  4. Idempotency & cleanup
    Handle interrupted runs by reading any existing change ID from state storage (S3, DynamoDB) so reruns dont create duplicate batches.
  5. Testing & CI linting
    Add unit tests that mock GetChange responses to validate your wait-logic. In integration environments, inject deliberate delays to ensure the loop tolerates long propagation times.
  6. Documentation comments
    Inline code comments should note that INSYNC means full global propagation and that skipping the wait can cause stale DNS answers during traffic-shift or health-check stages.

This control removes race conditions caused by Route 53s eventual consistency and ensures each deployment step operates on authoritative, up-to-date DNS data.

References

  • Amazon Route 53 API Reference
  • Route 53 DNS best practices

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation

countermeasure.name: Prevent VPC loop by separating Resolver rule and inbound endpoint associations
countermeasure.desc:
Never associate the same VPC with both (a) a Route 53 Resolver inbound endpoint and (b) a forwarding (outbound) Resolver rule that targets that endpoint. Doing so creates a circular DNS pathqueries leave the VPC through the rule, hit the inbound endpoint in the very same VPC, and bounce indefinitely until Resolver throttles them.

Implementation guidance

  1. Design the topology
    • Host inbound endpoints in a dedicated DNS-VPC.
    • Keep forwarding rules in other VPCs that need to query the inbound endpoint.
  2. Share rules safely
    • Use AWS Resource Access Manager (AWS RAM) to share the forwarding rules with spoke VPCs or accounts instead of associating them directly to the DNS-VPC.
  3. Create and associate resources

aws route53resolver create-resolver-endpoint --creator-request-id dns-ep \
   --direction INBOUND --ip-addresses SubnetId=subnet-a,Ip=10.0.1.10 SubnetId=subnet-b,Ip=10.0.2.10

aws route53resolver create-resolver-rule --creator-request-id fwd-rule \
   --rule-type FORWARD --domain-name corp.example.com \
   --target-ips Ip=10.0.1.10,Port=53 Ip=10.0.2.10,Port=53
 

  • Do not run associate-resolver-rule with the DNS-VPC ID; instead associate it with each spoke VPC (or share via RAM).
  1. Validate
    • Run list-resolver-rule-associations daily (or an AWS Config custom rule) to flag any VPC that shows up in both an inbound endpoint and the rule it forwards to.
    • Watch Resolver CloudWatch metrics for sudden spikes in DroppedQueries or ServFailpossible signs of a loop.
  2. Operational review
    • Re-confirm associations after every VPC peering, AWS RAM share, or network change.
    • Document the pattern in your IaC modules so reviews and automated tests catch mis-associations before deployment.

Following this pattern eliminates routing loops, preserves Resolver capacity, and lets you centralize DNS services without compromising VPC isolation.

References

  • Avoid loop configurations with Resolver endpoints
  • Best practices for Resolver

countermeasure.name: Set Route 53 record TTLs based on record stability
countermeasure.desc:
Configure the TTL (time-to-live) of every Amazon Route 53 DNS record so that it falls between 60 s and 172 800 s (1 min48 h), choosing the value according to how often the record is expected to change:

  1. Dynamic or health-checked records (failover, latency, geoproximity, weighted, alias with health checks).
    • Set TTL to 60120 s so that resolvers refresh quickly after a failover event or an automated change.
  2. Static or rarely changing records (static web sites, mail servers, alias to CloudFront/S3, etc.).
    • Use a longer TTL 3 600 s up to 172 800 sto improve resolver-side caching, lower query volume, and reduce cost.
  3. Planned changes (IP migration, provider cut-over, major DNS re-architecture).
    • 4872 h before the change, temporarily lower TTL to ~60 s for the affected records so that caches age out before the cut-over.
    • Perform and verify the change.
    • Restore the original longer TTL once the new configuration is stable (typically a few hours after validation).

Automate the rule in infrastructure-as-code templates (CloudFormation/Terraform) or CI/CD linting so any TTL outside the allowed range triggers a build failure. Add CloudWatch metrics or Config Rules to alert on TTL drift.

References

  • Best practices for Amazon Route 53 DNS Documentacin de AWS
  • DNS best practices for Amazon Route 53

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-20 Secure Name/address Resolution Service (authoritative Source)
SC-21 Secure Name/address Resolution Service (recursive or Caching Resolver)

countermeasure.name: Use multivalue answer routing to limit DNS response size
countermeasure.desc:
Configure DNS records that have many endpoints (for example, multiple web-server IPs) as multivalue answer routing records in Amazon Route 53. Multivalue answer routing returns a random subset of up to eight healthy records, which keeps typical UDP responses below the 512-byte limit defined in the DNS specification and avoids packet truncation or forced TCP retries.

Implementation steps

  1. Identify large record sets Any A, AAAA, or CNAME record whose wire-format size could exceed 512 bytes ( >25 IPv4 or >10 IPv6 addresses) is a candidate.
  2. Create multivalue answer records In the Route 53 console or IaC template, choose Multivalue answer and list every endpoint value. Attachor reuseRoute 53 health checks so only healthy targets are served.
  3. Validate size Use dig +bufsize=512 <name> or dnsperf against the public resolver to confirm that the UDP answer flag TC=0 (not truncated).
  4. Tune TTL and health-check settings Set TTL to 60300 s for volatile pools; 300900 s for stable pools. Keep health-check interval at 30 s (or 10 s for critical services) with a failure threshold of 35 probes.
  5. Monitor and alert Enable Route 53 query logging and CloudWatch metrics (DNSQueries, HealthCheckStatus). Add a CloudWatch alarm that fires when health checks fail or query errors rise.
  6. Automate enforcement Add an AWS Config custom rule or CI/CD linter that fails a deployment if:
    • Record type is Simple and size estimate > 512 bytes, or
    • Multivalue record has no health check.
  7. Periodic review Quarterly, recalculate record size after adding or retiring endpoints, and rerun validation tests. Update health-check targets and TTLs as architecture evolves.

Following this approach keeps DNS responses lightweight and standards-compliant while still providing high availability through health-checked, randomly rotated answers.

references

  • Multivalue answer routing returns up to eight healthy records
  • DNS responses over UDP are limited to 512 bytes

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events

countermeasure.name: Use Route 53 alias records instead of CNAMEs for AWS and same-zone targets
countermeasure.desc:
Replace every CNAME that points to an AWS-managed resource (CloudFront, S3 website endpoint, ELB/NLB, API Gateway, CloudFront, VPC interface endpoint, etc.) or to another record in the same hosted zonewith a Route 53 alias A/AAAA record. Alias records are resolved directly by Route 53, so clients receive the final A/AAAA answer in a single round-trip, which lowers latency, eliminates an extra lookup for the CNAME target, works at the zone apex (where CNAMEs are illegal), and incurs no query charges.

Implementation steps

  1. Inventory candidates
    • Run aws route53 list-resource-record-sets --hosted-zone-id Z123 or parse your IaC templates to find CNAME records.
    • Flag any CNAME whose value ends in amazonaws.com or whose target domain is inside the same hosted zone.
  2. Create the alias record
    • Console: Type A (or AAAA for IPv6) Alias Yes Alias target select the AWS resource or Alias to another record in this zone.
    • IaC example (CloudFormation):
    • RootAlias:
       Type: AWS::Route53::RecordSet
       Properties:
         HostedZoneName: example.com.
         Name: example.com.
         Type: A
         AliasTarget:
           HostedZoneId: !GetAtt MyLoadBalancer.CanonicalHostedZoneID
           DNSName: !GetAtt MyLoadBalancer.DNSName
    • Enable EvaluateTargetHealth when the target supports health checks (ELB, CloudFront).
  3. Retire the CNAME Delete or comment out the old record to prevent conflicts.
  4. Validate resolution dig +nocmd example.com A +short should now return IPs directly; no CNAME line appears.
  5. Automate enforcement
    • Add a linter or AWS Config custom rule that fails a commit if it introduces a CNAME whose target ends with amazonaws.com or matches the hosted-zone domain.
    • Include a unit test in your pipeline that runs list-resource-record-sets and asserts zero such CNAMEs.
  6. Periodic review Re-run the inventory quarterly or whenever new AWS services are introduced, ensuring new endpoints use alias records by default.

This control shortens DNS resolution time, removes the apex-record limitation, and cuts Route 53 query costs while keeping your zone files cleaner and easier to audit.

references

  • Choosing between alias and non-alias records
  • How to create alias records for AWS services

PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Oversized DNS responses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Oversized DNS responses occur when Route 53 returns records so largedue to extensive RRsets, DNSSEC signatures, or long TXT entriesthat they exceed typical UDP size limits or require fragmentation, leading to resolution failures or enabling amplification attacks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, misconfigured DNS administrators, and automated scanners.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Publishing very large TXT/SPF/DMARC records or including DNSSEC RRSIGs without adequate size controls.
    • Crafting DNS queries (e.g. ANY or EDNS options) that force Route 53 to return the full record set.
    • Exploiting the large responses for DNS amplification by spoofing victim IPs.

Impacts

  • Resolution Failures: Fragmented or truncated UDP responses may be dropped by resolvers or firewalls, causing lookup timeouts.
  • DoS on Resolvers: Large or fragmented packets consume bandwidth and CPU on recursive resolvers or clients.
  • Amplification Attacks: Attackers leverage the size disparity between small queries and large responses to flood victims with DNS traffic.
  • Increased Latency: Even successful TCP fallback queries incur delays, degrading application performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. TXT Record Bloat: A domain owner publishes an excessively long SPF record (>4 KB). Many recursive resolvers truncate the UDP response, leading to email delivery failures.
  2. DNSSEC Overhead: Enabling DNSSEC on a busy zone without size tuning causes RRSIGs to bloat responses; firewalls block fragmented packets, making the domain unreachable.
  3. Reflection Amplification: An attacker sends forged ANY queries to Route 53 for a zone with hundreds of A records, causing large UDP replies to flood a victims IP, overwhelming their network.

threat.name: Unoptimized resolver security groups
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unoptimized Resolver security groups occur when the AWS Route 53 Resolver endpoints are placed in security groups with overly permissive rules or missing necessary restrictions, exposing DNS resolution traffic to unauthorized sources or destinations.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised EC2 instances.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Ingress rules allowing UDP/TCP 53 from any IP (0.0.0.0/0), letting outsiders query or poison internal DNS.
    • Egress rules permitting unrestricted outbound DNS, enabling malware to exfiltrate data via DNS tunnels.
    • Lack of network-level separation between resolver endpoints and untrusted subnets or VPCs.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized DNS Queries: Attackers can enumerate internal hostnames or poison caches.
  • Data Exfiltration: Malicious payloads hidden in DNS requests/responses.
  • Service Disruption: Flooding or spoofing attacks against the resolver degrade or halt name resolution.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised hosts use open resolver rules to move across network segments.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open UDP 53 Ingress: A security group allows DNS queries from the Internet; an attacker routinely queries internal services, mapping out infrastructure.
  2. Unrestricted Egress for Tunneling: Malware on an EC2 spins up DNS tunneling over the resolvers egress port to exfiltrate confidential data.
  3. Cross-VPC Misrouting: A shared security group between public and private subnets lets a public-facing instance inject poisoned responses into the resolver, corrupting name resolution for all private workloads.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: DNS TTL misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured DNS TTLseither set too high or too lowcan delay record updates or overwhelm resolvers with excessive queries, hindering failover agility and service performance.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators and external attackers.
  • Vectors:
    • High TTLs prolong caching of outdated or poisoned records.
    • Low TTLs trigger surges of recursive lookups, straining DNS infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Extended Outages: Legitimate DNS changes (e.g., failover) dont propagate until TTL expiry.
  • Performance Degradation & Cost Spikes: Flooded resolvers and Route 53 query charges rise sharply.
  • Stale or Poisoned Caches: Attackers spoofed records persist longer under long TTLs.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stale Endpoint: A 24-hour TTL keeps users pointing at a compromised IP for a full day after a breach.
  2. Resolver Overload: A 5-second TTL in production triggers millions of lookups per minute, throttling DNS services.
  3. Cache Poisoning: During a lookup, an attacker injects a fake record; a 12-hour TTL lets the malicious entry persist across client caches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Suboptimal alias record usage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Suboptimal alias record usage occurs when Route 53 alias records are configured without appropriate health checks, routing policies, or alignment with the underlying resources availability zones. This can lead to stale DNS mappings, unexpected failover behavior, or dependency on single points of failure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, misconfigured automation, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Pointing an alias to a resource (e.g. ELB, CloudFront) without enabling health checks, so DNS never updates when the target fails.
    • Using a simple alias for cross-account or cross-region resources without proper routing policies, leading to stale caches.
    • Automating alias updates via scripts that fail silently, leaving outdated records in place.

Impacts

  • Extended Outages: Clients continue resolving to unhealthy endpoints, delaying failover.
  • Traffic Misrouting: Requests sent to decommissioned or wrong resources.
  • Operational Complexity: Difficult to audit and maintain alias targets, increasing error rates and MTTR.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Health-Check Omission: An alias api.example.com points to an ELB but lacks a linked health check; when the ELB goes down, traffic isnt rerouted to the standby, causing sustained downtime.
  2. Cross-Region Staleness: A dev team aliases db.example.com to a read-replica in another region for DR testing without weighted routing; DNS caches remain pointed at the DR instance even after failback.
  3. Automation Glitch: A CI/CD job updates an alias following deployment but the scripts IAM role lacks permission to change records; the old alias persists, sending users to an outdated backend.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

threat.name: Routing loop configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Routing loop configurations occur when DNS records unintentionally refer queries in a circular mannersuch as CNAMEs pointing at each other or alias records cascading between zonescausing resolvers to loop indefinitely rather than resolve to an endpoint.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, misconfigured automation scripts, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Creating CNAME records that point at each other (A B, B A).
    • Alias (ALIAS/ANAME) records across hosted zones that redirect back in a circle.
    • Scripting zone updates without detecting circular dependencies.

Impacts

  • Resolution Failures: Clients receive SERVFAIL or timeout after exhausting DNS retries.
  • Service Outages: Applications and APIs become unreachable due to broken name resolution.
  • Increased Latency & Load: Resolvers and authoritative servers waste cycles chasing loops, degrading performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental CNAME Loop: An admin adds app.example.com api.example.com and api.example.com app.example.com, causing every lookup to loop until timeouts.
  2. Cross-Zone Alias Loop: A GeoDNS policy points eu.example.com as an alias to us.example.com, and vice versa for us.example.com, preventing traffic from ever resolving.
  3. Malicious Automation: A compromised CI/CD job injects circular alias records into multiple zones, creating widespread DNS failures across services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Improper DNS delegation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Improper DNS delegation occurs when a zone or subdomains NS records point to incorrect, outdated, or attacker-controlled name servers. This misconfiguration lets malicious parties answer DNS queries for that domain, enabling spoofing, subdomain takeover, or traffic hijacking.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Delegating a subdomain to name servers under attacker control.
    • Failing to update NS records after migrating DNS zones, leaving stale delegations.
    • Omitting glue records for child zones, causing resolvers to fall back to rogue servers.

Impacts

  • Traffic Hijacking: Users and services resolve to malicious endpoints.
  • Subdomain Takeover: Attackers serve content or APIs under your namespace.
  • Phishing & Data Theft: Malicious sites impersonate legitimate services.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate DNS responses are blocked or misrouted, causing downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Attacker-Controlled NS: A subdomain api.example.com is delegated to NS records at ns1.evil.com. The attacker runs ns1.evil.com, resolving api.example.com to their server and intercepting API traffic.
  2. Stale Delegation: After moving blog.example.com to a new DNS provider, the old NS entries remain published. An attacker registers the old providers account and takes over the subdomain.
  3. Missing Glue Records: A child zone dev.example.com lacks glue records at the parent. Resolvers fall back to arbitrary servers that response with malicious IPs, redirecting development traffic to fake resources.

threat.name: Health check misconfigurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured health checkssuch as incorrect endpoints, overly strict thresholds, or wrong protocolscan cause Route 53 to mark healthy resources as unhealthy (or vice versa), leading to unintended traffic routing or failover.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, automation errors, and external attackers.
  • Vectors:
    • Pointing health checks at wrong paths or ports.
    • Setting aggressive failure thresholds or unreasonably low intervals.
    • Using HTTP checks against services that require HTTPS or custom headers.

Impacts

  • Unplanned Failover: Healthy endpoints are bypassed, routing traffic to under-provisioned backups.
  • Service Flapping: Transient errors trigger frequent DNS updates, causing resolution instability.
  • Extended Outages: False unhealthy states prevent traffic to available resources, increasing downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Path Mismatch: A health check targets /healthz but the service uses /status; Route 53 flags the primary as down and shifts traffic to an overloaded secondary.
  2. Threshold Abuse: An attacker induces brief spikes in response time; overly strict failure settings mark the endpoint unhealthy, triggering unwanted failover.
  3. Protocol Error: A check is configured as HTTP on an HTTPS-only service, causing constant failures and DNS flapping between records.

threat.name: Single-AZ resolver endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A single-AZ Route 53 Resolver endpoint creates a single point of failure: if that Availability Zone experiences an outage or network disruption, DNS resolution for dependent resources breaks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: AWS infrastructure failures, network disruptions, and targeted DDoS against the AZ.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • AZ-wide power or network outage taking the resolver endpoint offline.
    • Saturation of the resolvers network interface via volumetric DNS floods.
    • Misconfiguration that routes all DNS traffic to the lone endpoint.

Impacts

  • Resolution Failure: EC2 instances and on-premise networks using the resolver lose name resolution.
  • Service Disruption: Applications dependent on internal DNS (service discovery, authentication) may fail.
  • Operational Risk: Teams cannot troubleshoot or apply fixes if DNS queries timeout.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Outage: A power fault knocks out the single resolver endpoint in us-east-1a, leaving downstream services unable to resolve database hostnames.
  2. Targeted DNS Flood: An attacker floods the resolvers ENI with spoofed DNS queries, saturating its capacity and causing legitimate lookups to drop.
  3. Misrouted Traffic: A VPC peering update accidentally directs all DNS queries to the lone resolver in one AZ, so when that AZs network ACL is changed, resolution across the VPC grid fails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Missing default routing policy
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When no default routing record is defined (e.g. in geolocation, latency, or weighted policies), queries that dont match any specific rule return NXDOMAIN, causing legitimate users to be unable to resolve the domain.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, misconfigured automation, and Puppet/CloudFormation bugs.
  • Vectors: Deploying geolocation or weighted policies without an all-other or default record; removing a catch-all record during updates.

Impacts

  • Partial Outages: Users in unhandled regions or error cases see DNS failures.
  • Lost Traffic & Revenue: Inaccessible services for subsets of clients.
  • Increased Support Load: Spike in help-desk tickets and incident investigations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Geolocation Gap: A site configures geolocation records for US and APAC but omits default. Users in Europe get NXDOMAIN and cannot reach the service.
  2. Weighted Misfire: Two weighted records exist at 50/50, but no default. During weighted evaluation errors, some queries fall through and fail, degrading availability.
  3. Failover Slip-Through: Primary and secondary failover records exist, but without a default, health-check misfires send traffic to nowhere, causing full DNS resolution failures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: DNS zone walking attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
DNS zone walking attacks allow adversaries to enumerate all DNS records in a hosted zoneeither by abusing misconfigured zone transfers (AXFR/IXFR) or leveraging DNSSEC NSEC/NSEC3 responsesrevealing the full namespace and infrastructure details.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated reconnaissance tools, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unauthorized AXFR/IXFR zone transfers due to lax ACLs on the Route 53 delegation.
    • Iterative DNSSEC NSEC/NSEC3 record traversal to list all names in a signed zone.
    • Abuse of wildcard or catch-all records that leak subdomain structures.

Impacts

  • Infrastructure Reconnaissance: Full visibility into hostnames, subdomains, and service endpoints.
  • Targeted Attack Facilitation: Enables precise phishing, vulnerability scanning, or lateral-movement planning.
  • Subdomain Takeover Risk: Identifies unused or delegatable subdomains ripe for takeover.
  • Privacy & Compliance Exposure: Disclosure of internal service names or project identifiers.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unrestricted Zone Transfer: An attacker issues an AXFR request against the NS records for corp.example.com and retrieves the entire record set, mapping internal mail, VPN, and API hosts.
  2. DNSSEC Enumeration: Despite disabled AXFR, the zone is DNSSEC-signed; the adversary uses NSEC records to walk the namespace, listing every *.dev.example.com and planning targeted exploits.
  3. Wildcard Leakage: A catch-all record (*.staging.example.com) inadvertently exposes subdomain names when queried, allowing attackers to discover forgotten test environments.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information

threat.name: Unverified DNS change propagation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unverified DNS change propagation occurs when updates to hosted zone records are assumed successful without validating that changes have correctly propagated to all DNS caches and resolvers. This can leave stale or malicious records in use, causing traffic misrouting or persistent vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, automation tools, and external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Failing to verify DNS record updates across geographic or ISP caches.
    • Automation scripts that push changes without post-deployment checks.
    • Attackers exploiting cached stale records (e.g. via DNS cache poisoning) that persist after intended updates.

Impacts

  • Traffic Misrouting: Users continue to resolve to decommissioned or compromised endpoints.
  • Security Gaps: Old configurations (e.g. exposing test endpoints or weakly secured servers) remain reachable.
  • Operational Confusion: Inconsistent resolution leads to troubleshooting delays and lost revenue.
  • Compliance Risks: Inability to ensure correct record removal can breach data-governance policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stale Entry Abuse: An administrator removes a dev.example.com test record but doesnt purge caches; attackers exploit the lingering DNS entry to access internal test servers.
  2. Cache Poisoning Persistence: After remediating a cache-poisoned A record, an attacker continues to intercept traffic because resolvers havent expired the poisoned entry.
  3. Automation Race Condition: A CI/CD job updates routing but skips validation; some regions still point at a deprecated service, causing intermittent failures for a subset of users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information

component.name: AWS Systems Manager
component.desc: AWS Systems Manager ensures that configurations are managed consistently across multiple regions

weakness.name: Insufficient resource identification
weakness.desc: Resources are not registered in the safety net systems, and/or additional unidentified resources exist. As such, additional weakness might be introduced.

weakness.name: Sensitive data is accessible
weakness.desc: Sensitive data is not encrypted and is exposed.

weakness.name: The instances are not patched with the latest vendor updates or are misconfigured
weakness.desc: The latest vendor updates that ensure that the systems are not vulnerable have not been applied to the systems.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that the compliance status of the AWS EC2 Systems Manager patch compliance is COMPLIANT or NON_COMPLIANT
countermeasure.desc:
Patches released by the vendor for systems that are in-scope for PCI DSS should be tested and validated before installation in production environment. Once deployed, security settings and controls should be validated to ensure that deployed patches have not impacted the security of the cardholder data environment (CDE).

If you use Amazon EC2 instances managed by AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager to patch managed instances in your CDE, ensure that the patches are successfully applied. To do this, check that the compliance status of the Amazon EC2 Systems Manager patch compliance is "COMPLIANT". Patch Manager can apply both operating systems and applications applicable patches.

This is a method used to protect system components and software from known vulnerabilities.

Remediation

To remediate noncompliant patches

This rule checks whether the compliance status of the Amazon EC2 Systems Manager patch compliance is COMPLIANT or NON_COMPLIANT. To find out more about patch compliance states, see the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

  1. Open the AWS Systems Manager console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/.
  2. In the navigation pane, under Node Management, choose Run Command.
  3. Choose Run command.
  4. Choose the radio button next to AWS-RunPatchBaseline and then change the Operation to Install.
  5. Choose Choose instances manually and then choose the noncompliant instance(s).
  6. Scroll to the bottom and then choose Run.
  7. After the command has completed, to monitor the new compliance status of your patched instances, in the navigation pane, choose Compliance.

reference.name: AWS PCI-DSS Controls

countermeasure.name: Ensure that the managed instances have an association compliance status of COMPLIANT
countermeasure.desc:
A State Manager association is a configuration that is assigned to your managed instances. The configuration defines the state that you want to maintain on your instances. For example, an association can specify that antivirus software must be installed and running on your instances, or that certain ports must be closed.

After you create one or more State Manager associations, compliance status information is immediately available to you in the console or in response to AWS CLI commands or corresponding Systems Manager API operations. For associations, Configuration Compliance shows statuses of Compliant or Non-compliant and the severity level assigned to the association, such as Critical or Medium. To learn more about State Manager association compliance, see About State Manager association compliance in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

If you use EC2 instances managed by Systems Manager to collect inventory for your cardholder data environment (CDE), make sure that the instances are successfully associated. To do this, check whether the compliance status of the Systems Manager association compliance is COMPLIANT. Using Systems Manager can help to maintain an inventory of system components that are in scope for PCI DSS. 

Remediation

A failed association can be related to different things, including targets and SSM document names. To remediate this issue, you must first identify and investigate the association. You can then update the association to correct the specific issue.

You can edit an association to specify a new name, schedule, severity level, or targets. After you edit an association, Systems Manager creates a new version.

To investigate and update a failed association

  1. Open the AWS Systems Manager console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/.
  2. In the navigation pane, under Node Management, choose Fleet Manager.
  3. Choose the instance ID that has an Association status of Failed.
  4. Choose View details.
  5. Choose Associations.
  6. Note the name of the association that has an Association status of Failed. This is the association that you need to investigate. You need to use the association name in the next step.
  7. In the navigation pane,under Node Management, choose State Manager. Search for the association name, then select the association.
  8. After you determine the issue, edit the failed association to correct the problem. For information on how to edit an association, see Edit an association.

reference.name: AWS PCI-DSS Controls

countermeasure.name: Tag all resources
countermeasure.desc:
Description:

Tags enable customers to categorize AWS resources in different ways, for example, by purpose, owner, or environment.

Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which customer's define. You should define a set of tags for the following items to help you track each instance's owner and operating environment, cost center, and other items.
  1. Amazon EC2 instances
  2. ELB
  3. EBS Volumes
  4. S3 Buckets

A resource may have up to 10 tags associated with key & value such as:
  • Key=tier, Value=app
  • Key=environment, Value=production
  • Key=costcenter, Value=sales
Remediation:

Tag all your 3 tier Web Application resources based on their tier membership (Web, App, Data), and your organizational requirements.

reference.name: PCI Cloud Compliance
Resource groups and tagging

countermeasure.name: Use only the SecureString parameter type for sensitive data
countermeasure.desc:
Use only the SecureString parameter type for sensitive data

Rationale:
Parameter Store, a capability of AWS Systems Manager, provides secure, hierarchical storage for configuration data management and secrets management. You can store data such as passwords, database strings, Amazon Machine Image (AMI) IDs, and license codes as parameter values.
A SecureString parameter is any sensitive data that needs to be stored and referenced in a secure manner. If you have data that you don't want users to alter or reference in plaintext, such as passwords or license keys, create those parameters using the SecureString datatype.

Remediation:
Do not store sensitive data in a String or StringList parameter. For all sensitive data that must remain encrypted, use only the SecureString parameter type.

How to create a parameter (console)

The following procedure walks you through the process of creating a parameter in the Parameter Store console. You can create String, StringList, and SecureString parameter types in the console.

To create a parameter

1. Open the AWS Systems Manager console.

2. In the navigation pane, choose Parameter Store.

or

If the AWS Systems Manager home page opens first, choose the menu icon to open the navigation pane, and then choose Parameter Store.

3. Choose Create parameter.

4. In the Name box, enter a hierarchy and a name. For example, enter /Test/helloWorld.

5. In the Description box, type a description that identifies this parameter as a test parameter.

6. For Parameter tier choose either Standard or Advanced. For more information about advanced parameters, see Managing parameter tiers.

7. For Type, choose String, StringList, or SecureString.

- If you choose String, the Data type field appears. If you are creating a parameter to hold the resource ID for an Amazon Machine Image (AMI), select aws:ec2:image. Otherwise, keep the default text selected.

- If you choose SecureString, the KMS Key ID field appears. If you don't provide an AWS Key Management Service AWS KMS key ID, a AWS KMS key Amazon Resource Name (ARN), an alias name, or an alias ARN, then the system uses alias/aws/ssm, which is the AWS managed key for Systems Manager. If you don't want to use this key, then you can use a customer managed key. For more information about AWS managed and customer managed keys, see AWS Key Management Service Concepts in the AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide.

Important
Parameter Store supports only symmetric KMS keys. You cannot use an asymmetric KMS key to encrypt your parameters.

- When creating a SecureString parameter in the console by using the key-id parameter with either a customer managed key alias name or an alias ARN, you must specify the prefix alias/ before the alias. Following is an ARN example.

arn:aws:kms:us-east-2:123456789012:alias/MyAliasName

Following is an alias name example.

alias/MyAliasName

8. In the Value box, type a value. For example, type This is my first parameter or ami-0dbf5ea29aEXAMPLE.

Note
Parameters can't be referenced or nested in the values of other parameters. You can't include {{}} or {{ssm:parameter-name}} in a parameter value.
If you chose SecureString, the value of the parameter is masked by default ("******") when you view it later on the parameter Overview tab. Choose Show to display the parameter value.

9. (Optional) In the Tags area, apply one or more tag key-value pairs to the parameter.

Tags are optional metadata that you assign to a resource. Tags allow you to categorize a resource in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, or environment. For example, you might want to tag a Systems Manager parameter to identify the type of resource to which it applies, the environment, or the type of configuration data referenced by the parameter. In this case, you could specify the following key-value pairs:

- Key=Resource,Value=S3bucket

- Key=OS,Value=Windows

- Key=ParameterType,Value=LicenseKey

10. Choose Create parameter.

11. In the parameters list, choose the name of the parameter you just created. Verify the details on the Overview tab. If you created a SecureString parameter, choose Show to view the unencrypted value.

Note
You can't change an advanced parameter to a standard parameter. If you no longer need an advanced parameter, or if you no longer want to incur charges for an advanced parameter, you must delete it and recreate it as a new standard parameter.

Impact:
None

reference.name: AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store
Create a Systems Manager parameter (console)
Data protection in AWS Systems Manager

test.steps:
Run the following command to verify the details of the parameter.

aws ssm get-parameters \ -name "the-parameter-name-you-specified" \ -with-decryption

Note
If you don't specify the with-decryption parameter, or if you specify the no-with-decryption parameter, the command returns an encrypted GUID.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized network access
threat.desc: Attackers could gain unauthorized network access to the resources through misconfigured ports or security network configurations.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc: Attackers can gain access to sensitive data when the data is in transit in clear text, or when the data is stored without encryption.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Control traffic using network ACLs
countermeasure.desc: Manage inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level by configuring network Access Control Lists (ACLs) in your VPC. Network ACLs act as stateless firewalls for your subnets, allowing you to set rules that permit or deny traffic based on IP protocol, port number, and source/destination IP address. To implement this, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, create or modify network ACLs, and associate them with the appropriate subnets. Regularly review and update ACL rules to enhance security and compliance.

countermeasure.name: Detect potential threats with Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Enable Amazon GuardDuty to continuously monitor VPC flow logs for malicious activity and potential security threats. GuardDuty uses machine learning and threat intelligence to analyze traffic patterns and detect anomalies. To implement this, activate GuardDuty in the AWS Management Console, configure it to ingest VPC flow logs, DNS logs, and CloudTrail event logs. Regularly review GuardDuty findings and take appropriate actions to mitigate identified threats, ensuring your VPC remains secure against evolving attack vectors.

countermeasure.name: Distribute subnets across multiple availability zones
countermeasure.desc: To ensure high availability, fault tolerance, and scalability of your applications hosted on Amazon VPC, create subnets in multiple Availability Zones (AZs) within the same AWS Region. An Availability Zone comprises one or more data centers with independent power, networking, and connectivity. By distributing subnets across multiple AZs, you can mitigate the risk of a single point of failure and enhance the resilience of your application against potential outages or failures in a single AZ. This approach provides redundancy and improves overall system reliability.

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs
countermeasure.desc: Implement VPC flow logs to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces within your VPC. This log data can help you monitor network traffic, identify potential security threats, diagnose network issues, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. To enable VPC Flow Logs, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, select your VPC, and create a new Flow Log, specifying the destination for the log data, such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs or an S3 bucket. Regularly review and analyze these logs for abnormal traffic patterns and security incidents.

Review findings to address any unintended access, ensuring robust network security.

To implement it, create a firewall in the AWS Management Console, configure rules to control inbound and outbound traffic, and associate the firewall with your VPC subnets. Regularly update and monitor these rules to ensure they align with your security policies and threat landscape.
